subject: p12433421
History: Alcoholic cirrhosis, question worsening pleural effusion. CHEST, TWO VIEWS. There is a small-to-moderate left effusion, somewhat improved compared with. There is also a small-to-moderate right effusion. On the lateral view, there is a rounded convexity at the right base posteriorly associated with the effusion, which appears new compared with and. Given the time and course, the most likely etiology is loculated fluid and that would be in keeping with the appearance on the abdominal CT. The heart is not enlarged, thought there is a left ventricular configuration. There is no CHF. There is atelectasis and volume loss at the left base. The left hemidiaphragm is obscured, unchanged.
Impression: 1 Small-to-moderate left effusion, less pronounced than on, with underlying volume loss. Underlying consolidation cannot be excluded. 2 Small-to-moderate right effusion. Convex appearance raises the question of loculated fluid. Please see comment.
